Award.AwardTitle: Molecular Tagging Techniques for Stratified Flow: Application to Boundary Mixing

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1067270
Rehmann

The transport of heat, salt, and contaminants is important to measure and predict in environmental flows. For example, water quality in lakes depends on vertical transport of heat and contaminants, and the transport of heat and salt in the ocean affects the global climate. To improve the measurement and modeling of transport, molecular tagging velocimetry and thermometry (MTV&T), which has been applied successfully in other engineering flows, will be extended for use in stratified flows. The technique will be applied in a laboratory model of mixing driven by internal waves at the boundary of lakes and oceans. Specific objectives of the project are to (1) extend MTV&T to salt-stratified flow, (2) quantify turbulence and mixing generated by long waves, and (3) determine the effect of intermittent forcing on the mixing and transport.

The intellectual merit of the proposed research comes from the ability to measure the mixing and turbulence in a boundary layer generated by internal waves in more detail than previously possible; MTV&T will provide two-dimensional fields of velocity, concentration, and flux while avoiding some of the pitfalls of other techniques. The proposed laboratory experiments start with a well-studied case to verify the molecular tagging technique and then extend previous laboratory work to study other factors that are important in interpreting field measurements. Concurrent field measurements will guide the design of the laboratory experiments and test the results from the lab. The proposed work exploits PI Rehmann's experience with measurements and modeling of boundary mixing and PI Hu?s expertise in advanced flow measurement and visualization techniques.

The broader impacts include training a graduate student, conducting outreach to schools, and applying molecular tagging methods to stratified flow. The outreach uses the connections that Rehmann and Hu have established with Iowa schools and programs to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups. Also, the proposed project involves the first application of the molecular tagging method to a stratified flow of environmental importance; because previous field measurements have shown that boundary mixing can control the basin-wide vertical transport in lakes and oceans, these experiments will provide valuable information for modeling contaminant transport in the environment. Furthermore, once the proposed work demonstrates the usefulness of molecular tagging for boundary mixing, it can be used in laboratory models of many other stratified flows in the environment.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A simple approach to predicting transport of heat, nutrients, and contaminants in lakes and oceans assumes that mixing is evenly distributed throughout the water body. However, observations in lakes and oceans over several decades have shown that the mixing is not uniform. Instead, much of the mixing occurs near the sloping sides of the water body. One mechanism for generating turbulence and mixing along a slope is critical reflection of internal waves. Like surface waves, internal waves result from displacing dense fluid into less dense fluid (e.g., cold water into warm water). Unlike surface waves, internal waves propagate at a fixed angle to the horizontal determined by temperature or salinity differences and the frequency of the disturbance. When an internal wave beam encounters a sloping boundary, the waves can reflect backward, reflect forward, or—if the angles of the beam and slope match—reflect critically, or along the slope (Figure 1). Critical or near-critical reflection leads to turbulence and mixing thought to be important in lakes and oceans.

Many researchers have studied internal waves interacting with boundaries in field experiments, laboratory experiments, and numerical simulations, but our work using laboratory imaging techniques forms—to our knowledge—the first two-dimensional measurements of the turbulence caused by near-critical reflection. We measured the turbulent kinetic energy (TKE), a measure of the energy in the turbulence fields, and its dissipation rate, which is commonly measured in lakes and oceans and used to estimate transport and mixing. The highest dissipation occurred in patches in a layer near the slope, and the dissipation dropped sharply outside the layer (Figure 2). For waves with forward reflection, high values of dissipation also appeared in regions outside the boundary layer (Figure 3). As in direct numerical simulations, regions of high TKE coincided with regions of high dissipation for all cases (Figure 4); the measurements suggest that TKE can be determined from measured values of dissipation. Although the internal waves caused high values of dissipation, the current observations combined with previous theoretical work suggests that little mixing will occur near the slope.

The results from this project extend previous knowledge on boundary mixing in lakes and oceans by providing more detail than previously available on turbulence caused by internal waves interacting with slopes. In particular, our work shows how the turbulence varies in space and time over the turbulent boundary layer. The findings here will affect limnology and oceanography by improving the interpretation of field experiments and modeling of mixing in lakes and oceans; these improvements can eventually affect issues such as ocean circulation and climate as well as contaminant transport in lakes. The project involved the training of two graduate students—who learned to design, conduct, and analyze laboratory experiments—and a postdoctoral researcher, who helped to supervise the students.
